solutions.sol_html: Solution: The temperature of a black body and the wavelength corresponding to its maximum intensity are related by the Wien's displacement law,\[\lambda_{m} T=b .\]The power radiated by a black body at temperature \( T \) having surface area \( A \) and emissivity \( e \) is given by the Stefan's law,\[Q=\sigma e A T^{4} .\]For a thin disc of radius \( r \) emitting from both surfaces, \( A=2 \pi r^{2} \). Eliminate \( T \) from above equations and substitute for \( A \) to get,\[Q=2 \pi \sigma e b^{4}\left(r^{2} / \lambda_{m}^{4}\right),\]which gives,\[\begin{aligned}Q_{A}: Q_{B}: Q_{C} & =\frac{r_{A}^{2}}{\lambda_{A}^{4}}: \frac{r_{B}^{2}}{\lambda_{B}^{4}}: \frac{r_{C}^{2}}{\lambda_{C}^{4}} \\& =0.049: 0.0625: 0.057\end{aligned}\]

Which of the following is correct the form of the Planck radiation formula in the limit for energy density \( \rho(\lambda) \) for wave length \( \lambda \) at absolute temperature \( T \)
(a) \( \rho(\lambda, T)=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{1}{\exp \left(h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right)-1} \)
(b) \( \rho(\lambda, T)=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{1}{\exp \left(h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right)+1} \)
(c) For large wave length \( h c / \lambda k_{B} T \ll 1 \quad \rho(\lambda, T)=\frac{8 \pi}{\lambda^{4}} k_{B} T \)
(d) For short wavelength \( h c / \lambda k_{B} T \gg 1 \rho(\lambda)=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \exp \left(-h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right) \)
questions.onlyq_text: Which of the following is correct the form of the Planck radiation formula in the limit for energy density \( \rho(\lambda) \) for wave length \( \lambda \) at absolute temperature \( T \)

options.option: (a) \( \rho(\lambda, T)=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{1}{\exp \left(h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right)-1} \)
(b) \( \rho(\lambda, T)=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{1}{\exp \left(h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right)+1} \)
(c) For large wave length \( h c / \lambda k_{B} T \ll 1 \quad \rho(\lambda, T)=\frac{8 \pi}{\lambda^{4}} k_{B} T \)
(d) For short wavelength \( h c / \lambda k_{B} T \gg 1 \rho(\lambda)=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \exp \left(-h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right) \)

questions.subject: PHYSICS

solutions.sol_html: Solution: (a) \( \rho(\lambda, T)=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{1}{\exp \left(h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right)-1} \)(b) for \( h c / \lambda k_{B} T \ll 1=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{1}{\left[1+\frac{h c}{\lambda k_{B} T}+\left(\frac{h c}{\lambda k_{B} T}\right)^{2}+\cdots\right]-1} \)In the linear approximation of the Taylor series expansion,\[\rho_{\lambda}(\lambda, T)=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{\lambda k_{B} T}{h c}=\frac{8 \pi}{\lambda^{4}} k_{B} T\](c) For \( h c / \lambda k_{B} T \gg 1 \) we have \( \exp \left(h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right) \gg 1 \) and\[\rho_{\lambda}(\lambda, T) \approx \frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{1}{\exp \left(h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right)}=\frac{8 \pi h c}{\lambda^{5}} \exp \left(-h c / \lambda k_{B} T\right)\]In this case \( h c / \lambda \gg k_{B} T \) and the discreteness of the cavity energy is obvious; the classical theory gives completely wrong predictions.
